qas.question: To which group did the people of the Catholic faith refer to themselves primarily?
After allowing for their religion, did the people of the Catholic faith see themselves as Serbian or Croatian?
Ivan Broz stated that a Dalmatian identifiying as a Serb was just as foreign as what two other ethnicities?
What did most Croatians who were Catholic see themselves a part of?
To what group were Macedonians loyal to first?
What did 30 Serbs see themselves over a span of 350 years?

plausible_answers.text: for a Dalmatian to identify oneself as a Serb was seen as foreign as identifying oneself as Macedonian or Greek

qas.question: What did most intellectuals and writers note about Dalmations?
What was Serbo-Croatian ideology not equal with in Dalmatia?

context: However, most intellectuals and writers from Dalmatia who used the Štokavian dialect and practiced the Catholic faith saw themselves as part of <b3_0>a <a1_0>Croatian<a1_0/> nation<b3_0/> as far back as the mid-16th to 17th centuries, some 300 years before Serbo-Croatian ideology appeared. Their loyalty was first and foremost to <a0_0><b4_0>Catholic Christendom<b4_0/><a0_0/>, but when they professed an ethnic identity, they referred to themselves as "Slovin" and "Illyrian" (a sort of forerunner of Catholic baroque pan-Slavism) and Croat – these 30-odd writers over the span of c. 350 years always saw themselves <b5_0>as Croats first<b5_0/> and never as part of a Serbian nation. It should also be noted that, in the pre-national era, Catholic religious orientation did not necessarily equate with <b7_0>Croat ethnic identity<b7_0/> in Dalmatia. A Croatian follower of Vuk Karadžić, Ivan Broz, noted that <b6_0>for a Dalmatian to identify oneself as a Serb was seen as foreign as identifying oneself as <a2_0>Macedonian or Greek<b6_0/><a2_0/>. Vatroslav Jagić pointed out in 1864:
